body:
hmm... seems like you hit a limitation here. In certain edge cases the way webpack generates code doesn't allow hoisting function correctly in circular dependencies. In your case you are executing a function of a module before runtime sees the import to that module (before evaluation of the module has started). The ESM spec allows that.

I guess this code would work in production due to module concatenation, which handles hoisting of function better.

As workaround you should be able to switch the order of imports to fix that.

In practice this edge case is pretty rare and in all the years since ESM integration in webpack exists it has not be reported before. It's rare because most code like this would break anyway since you would not be able to access any variable of the scope of the shared module, since they are all still in TDZ or undefined.

> I guess this code would work in production due to module concatenation, which handles hoisting of function better.

In this case there's also a runtime error in production mode (`Uncaught ReferenceError: Cannot access 't' before initialization` under 5.0.0-beta.16, using default `--mode production` behavior with no config file). But agreed that this case seems very rare and rewriting to avoid it is a workable solution.

Has there been thought to including something like circular-dependency-plugin by default? I think it could help head off these kinds of issues by catching circular dependencies early and strongly recommending against them / encouraging a pattern of whitelisting exceptions for the few cases they're needed. I like that Rollup warns on this circular dependency case. But maybe that's too opinionated to include in the core?

Thanks for looking into this @sokra! So it seems like there are a lot of good reasons to close this out as "wontfix" for now. It's trivial to rewrite any code affected by this, sounds like it's very rare for the issue to come up, and it only blew up in a production app for me in an unexpected way (following a Babel upgrade) because an older Babel configuration was somehow masking the preexisting issue.

I can close this out and open a new separate issue for the bug with unnamed function declaration in default export with clearer repro for that.

issue.title: keep function declarations when using export default

Through "loaders", modules can be CommonJs, AMD, ES6 modules, CSS, Images, JSON, Coffeescript, LESS, ... and your custom stuff.

issue.title: HMR not propagating correctly with circular imports and re-exports

repository.name: webpack
repository.description: A bundler for javascript and friends. Packs many modules into a few bundled assets. Code Splitting allows for loading parts of the application on demand. Through "loaders", modules can be CommonJs, AMD, ES6 modules, CSS, Images, JSON, Coffeescript, LESS, ... and your custom stuff.

issue.body:
# Bug report

**What is the current behavior?**

At import time, the dependency will be `undefined`, and the update cannot be called correctly after the first HMR cycle.

**If the current behavior is a bug, please provide the steps to reproduce.**

Reproducible Repo:
https://github.com/pmmmwh/refresh-cycle-repro

Run `yarn start` and then try to edit `SurveyOverview.js`, like returning `101` instead of `100` in the function.

The `module.hot.accept()` calls are intentionally placed for only those files - they are recognized as "boundaries" for HMR to happen in React Fast Refresh world.

**What is the expected behavior?**

The dependency should be the exact exports and thus calls to it should work correctly, even after HMR.

To be honest, I'm not sure if this is too extreme/specific of an edge case which is hitting the boundaries of Webpack's CJS/ESM module system. It involves re-exports and circular dependencies (both need to be related to an unaccepted dependency for this issue to rise) which, in practice, are both very difficult to deal with properly in CJS. To my understanding, Webpack's module system aligns closer to CJS - so I'm also not sure if this can be solved at all.

This might be related to #10870.
Related issue for FR: pmmmwh/react-refresh-webpack-plugin#81

**Other relevant information:**

Webpack version: 4.43.0
Node.js version: 14.4.0
Operating System: macOS 10.15.5
Additional tools: None

body: @jedwards1211 Sorry for delay, is the problem still valid? Also feel free to send a PR in any cases
Yeah still valid, okay I'll try to work on a PR
